title: Can an illustration of an animal silhouette be copyrighted? - Quora

response.answer_text: The answers so far have a mistaken understanding of copyright law, insofar as U.S. law is involved. Let’s assume the illustration was made in the U.S., so that we know your question is about U.S. law. If so, the correct answer can be found here: What Does Copyright Protect? In a nutshell, “Copyright … protects original works of authorship including literary, dramatic, musical, and artistic works…” that are fixed in a tangible medium. Thus, there are only a few very simple questions that need to be answered to know whether your illustration is protected by copyright: Did you make the illustration? Is it on paper or other tangible medium? Was it your original work? Was there even a “slight amount” of originality or creative expression? If yes, it is protected by copyright, from the moment you made the illustration. Registering your copyright in your illustration is a different matter, but that’s not what the question asked. Several of the other answers conflate the existence of copyright protection with meaningful enforcement of your copyright. Those are not the same thing, at all. Copyright protects the author only against someone else copying their creative expression. Thus, anyone else who creates an illustration of an animal silhouette, without copying your specific version of it (or someone else’s), has a copyright in their illustration, too. Proving copyright infringement requires (simplifying here) access to your copyrighted work and substantial similarity between your work and the alleged copy. If your illustration is simple, it’s difficult to show that someone else’s illustration is substantially similar. The result is that your copyright protection is probably very limited, but that doesn’t mean that your illustration isn’t protected by copyright.

In principle, yes. If you took a photo of the Grand Canyon, it is your picture. You decided how to frame it, the angle, the time of day, etc. So you can copyright that picture. But the only benefit of copyright is to prevent someone else from using your “art” without permission or payment. Therefore, it must be something sufficiently unique that a judge could tell when someone has used YOUR image, as opposed to having created one from scratch. In fact, it should be sufficiently unique that no one else is likely to have accidentally reproduced an image indistinguishable from yours. The silhouette of a teapot probably won’t cut it. A “generic” silhouette of a roadrunner (meep! meep!) may be too simple to copyright. But if no one has used it as a trademark for a business, you might be able to get it trademarked. This would not prevent others from copying and sharing your trademark - but if your business is successful, and a competitor comes along and tries to sell their product or services using your trademarked logo, they could be sued for attempting to pass their poorly made, knock-off products as yours, or attempting to make it appear that their services are endorsed by your company.

I’ll start by assuming this is asked as it applies to the United States. The answer is, yes it can — but there’s more information needed to say whether that’s true in your case. The most relevant thing you need to read is the concept of threshold of originality. This is what determines whether your silhouette is sufficiently unique to be eligible for copyright protection. And keep in mind, my answer is based on experience in publishing and design, not as an intellectual-property attorney. The protection of an illustration can get complicated depending on how it’s used, its form, and whether it needs to be trademarked. But everything hinges on the threshold of originality, so read up on that. Thanks for the A2A! [Answered: Can an illustration of an animal silhouette be copyrighted?]

Yes. It’s an origiinal work. If you do it yourself and not for an employer, you are the copyright holder (if you register it your rights increase). However, you’re working in an area that’s not conduciv e to a lot of originality—any competent sketch artist or digital artist can produce a silhouettte of any animal, and unless it’s just ab out a line-by-line precise copy of your original, the courts probably would not consider it an infringment. Consider how many famous painters have produced images of London Bridge or the Colisseum—so long as the newer painting was not identical, it was not plagiarism.

Tough to tell, it has to be really unique and “creative.”

Probably not. Works without enough "originality" (creativity) to merit copyright protection such as titles, names, short phrases and slogans, familiar symbols or designs, font design, ingredients or contents, facts, blank forms, etc. cannot be copyrighted. If it’s just a basic shape that anyone looking at a cat could draw, then there’s no IP in creating that. And if you copyright your outline of a cat, what do you plan to do if someone else makes the shape of a cat that looks very similar to yours?
